title: 10 ways to hit your 10-a-day, with minimum effort

text:
10 easy ways to eat your 10-a-day of fruit and vegetables Credit: TOBIAS SCHWARZ/AFP Saffron Alexander  22pm 
T he "five-a-day" rule should be doubled to "10-a-day" , according to a new study which says that increasing your intake of fruit and vegetables could dramatically decrease the chance of disease. 
The study, from Imperial College London , analysed data from 95 studies and found that eating 800g of fruit and vegetables a day can reduce the chance of having a stroke by a third, while the risk of heart disease drops by nearly a quarter. 
Lead author Dr Dagfinn Aune, from the School of Public Health at Imperial, said: "It is clear from this work that a high intake of fruit and vegetables holds tremendous health benefits, and we should try to increase their intake in our diet." 
Nutritionists, however, have warned that telling people to double their daily fruit and vegetable intake could add pressure and create "unrealistic expectations" - so we've made it easy for you: 10 easy ways to enjoy your 10-a-day with minimal fuss Whizz up a smoothie Credit: Brent Hofacker/Alamy 
A ccording to government guidelines, smoothies can count for up to two portions of your daily intake of fruit and vegetables - and they're incredibly Instagram friendly, so you can rack up those likes while boosting your health. 
Don't go overboard, though: a Department of Health spokesperson said: "Our advice is to limit the fruit and vegetables intake from just juice and smoothies, as the processing reduces the amount of fibre and increases the amount of sugar in the final product which can damage your teeth. 
"This is why we recommend that smoothies should count for no more than two of your five a day." Jazz up your cereal A post shared by Hannah | Vegan üå± | 22 | üìçUK üá¨üáß (@prosperoushealthylife) on Feb 22, 2017 at 8:16am PST 
Y our morning meal doesn't have to be a bowl of sugar swimming in milk. You can turn it into a healthier masterpiece simply by adding some of your favourite fruits on top. 
Get creative and add strawberries, bananas, cranberries, almonds - whatever you fancy - and watch more of those Instagram likes start to roll in. Swap crisps for carrots and cucumbers Credit: Tatjana Baibakova/Alamy 
I f you have a bad habit of snacking throughout the day, try swapping your crisps for a bowl of carrot and cucumber sticks. 
If you want to jazz it up a little, make a homemade hummus dip or even a healthy yogurt to give it a little more flavour. Chop up a banana A post shared by Annie Jaffrey (@anniejaffrey) on Jan 15, 2017 at 8:55am PST 
Y ou could slather your toast in butter or jam or honey (or whatever your spread of choice is), before you then sprinkle some other, equally unhealthy, topping over the top - or you could take the opportunity to squeeze in one of your 10-a-day and peel a banana. 
Either chop it up into thin slices and enjoy like above, or mash it up until it gets an almost pulp-like texture and spread it over your toast like you would butter or jam. Slurp some soup Credit: LOUISE HAGGER 
T he British Heart Foundation recommend upping your servings of vegetable soup to meet your daily fruit and vegetable intake. 
Add anything you like to the mix - carrots, onions, sweet potatoes, mushrooms, and more - and either leave the soup chunky so it's more like a stew, or blitz until smooth. For a light and simple recipe, try Louise Parker's Thai tofu and vegetable soup . Get grating Credit: Alamy 
A n easy way of adding some vegetables to what might otherwise be not a particularly healthy dish, is to simply grate a favourite vegetable and sprinkle it over your meal. Fling some berries in the freezer A post shared by Sharon (@sharon_erichsen) on Jan 23, 2017 at 3:12am PST 
T eam yogurt with frozen berries and enjoy a light snack that all counts towards your daily fruit and vegetable intake. Indulge yourself Credit: Andrew Crowley 
J ust because you're trying to up your fruit and veg intake, it doesn't mean you have to forgo some of your favourite things. And that includes ice cream. 
Deliciously Ella's mango and banana ice cream recipe is deceptively healthy and simple to make. Knock up a stir-fry Credit: Haarala Hamilton 
S tir-frying is one of the easiest and quickest ways to add some extra vegetables to your diet. Try Kay Plunkett-Hogge‚Äôs version made with Siamese watercress - or you can substitute tatsoi greens or cavolo nero. And finally... sneak them into a cocktail Credit: DAVID BROOKS HALL 
A fter a long day of healthy eating you deserve a treat. But all that hard work doesn't have to go to waste, not when you can get yourself a delicious and healthy vegetable cocktail that still counts towards your daily goal. 
The 'Caballero' cocktail at the Juniper bar in Edinburgh puts picked radish centre stage. The creator of the cocktail, Chlo√´ Colvin, said: "I used Gin mare for a Spanish theme, and savoury rosemary and thyme botanicals to make a more complex martini. I feel quite passionately about using traditional cooking methods such as pickling so I added a homemade pickled radish as a quirky touch and a nod to forgotten techniques."
